question_title: In which region will Netflix have higher revenues in Q1 2026: Latin America or Asia-Pacific?
summary: Netflix LATAM and APAC revenues have been remarkably close throughout 2025, with both regions generating nearly identical quarterly revenue (~$1.26B in Q1, ~$1.31B in Q2, ~$1.37B in Q3, ~$1.42B in Q4). In Q3 2025, the most precise data point (from the 10-Q), LATAM led by just $2.35M. However, APAC has consistently grown faster than LATAM every quarter (23% vs 8% in Q1, 17% vs 15% in Q4), though the gap is narrowing. From an essentially equal base in Q1 2025 (~$1.26B each), APAC's persistent growth advantage suggests it should edge ahead in Q1 2026. However, the convergence of growth rates and FX uncertainty create meaningful probability for either outcome. A tie (exact same dollar amount) is virtually impossible given reporting precision to thousands of dollars.

factors.description: APAC has grown faster than LATAM every quarter in 2025 (17% vs 15% in Q4 2025), and from a near-equal Q1 2025 base, faster growth yields higher revenue
The growth rate gap has narrowed dramatically from 15pp (Q1) to 2pp (Q4), meaning the advantage could fully converge or reverse by Q1 2026
Trend from Q3 2025 (LATAM barely ahead by $2.35M) to Q4 2025 (essentially tied) suggests APAC is overtaking LATAM
LATAM growth has been accelerating (8% → 15%), possibly driven by pricing, which could match or exceed APAC's decelerating growth (23% → 17%)
FX uncertainty: Latin American currencies (BRL, MXN) and Asian currencies (JPY, KRW) can swing results either way by tens of millions
